docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration said on Wednesday that it had adopted regulations to require that cigarettes sold in New York State be manufactured with paper that can extinguish itself. The so-called fire-safe cigarettes stop burning if no one is puffing on them. Supporters of the new rules, which go into effect on June 28, say the cigarettes will prevent many of the fires now caused by smokers who leave cigarettes unattended, typically when they fall asleep and bedding or upholstery catches fire.

headline.main: Smoke-Filled Bars Are Gone, but So Is Liberty

docs.abstract: Patrick Gordon letter on Dec 28 article notes loss of jobs in lower Manhattan bars that have closed since smoking ban took effect

headline.main: Smoke-Filled Bars Are Gone, but So Is Liberty

docs.abstract: Dr Edward Anselm letter on Dec 28 article says there are health and economic benefits resulting from New York City's ban on smoking in bars and restaurants
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The discussion of the economic effects of New York City's tough regulation banning smoking in bars and restaurants is by no means complete (front page, Dec. 28).
